title: Policeman, truck driver, hotel maintenance man: The Cape Verde team with a World Champs wildcard
content:

Policeman, truck driver, hotel maintenance man: The Cape Verde team with a World Champs wildcard

Dave Savage only became coach of the Cape Verde national cycling team because he went to the country on holiday. Fast forward to today and Savage is leading a team of six riders granted a wildcard invitation for what the UCI has labelled the biggest World Championships ever, with more than 200 rainbow jerseys up for grabs over the next 10 days.

‘My wife and I go to Cape Verde every couple of years,’ says Savage. ‘In May last year, we went and saw a lot of kids not in school. We figured out that there were very few bikes, and the minibuses that would take the kids to school often couldn’t afford to run because of fuel prices.’

Instead of simply getting back to thumbing through his holiday reading on the beach, Savage, who runs his own cycling and triathlon training company, was compelled to do something about what he saw. He contacted the Cape Verde Cycling Federation – or Federação Cabo-verdiana de Ciclismo – offering help in the form of a fundraiser that bought bicycles to be distributed as the federation saw fit. As a thank you for his efforts, the FCC invited him back to race at their nationals last December.

No more than 30 riders started Cape Verde’s 75km national road race or the 16km time-trial. But Savage was among them. ‘I was buzzing,’ he says. ‘But I wasn’t really there to race – I was just there as a guest… which is where I met these boys and saw that here were these beautiful, raw diamonds.’

Diamonds in the rough of 10 volcanic islands (nine of them inhabited) with a population of just over 500,000 people. Diamonds who are not part of a system beyond their local club or bike shop, and who are either still studying or recently left their education, or who balance their training with regular day jobs. Many of them have never stepped foot out of Cape Verde – until now.

‘There was so much talent that wasn’t nurtured, wasn’t guided,’ says Savage. ‘The ambitions of the riders are very high. With a bit of fine-tuning, these boys can be incredibly good. I can’t say they’ll make GC in a Grand Tour within a certain time. But just to give them the opportunity to try [is the important thing].

‘Genetically, I swear there is something about these boys that is so conducive to cycling… And the lack of vices [helps]. None of them drink alcohol. There is no Burger King. There’s not much in the way of employment, so they have time on their hands.’

Again, Savage couldn’t ignore the drive to do something with what was in front of him: ‘I offered to coach them. They said, “Yes please.” And here we are.’

Talk about a busman’s holiday.

From one island to another

By ‘here’, Savage means the ferry to Yarmouth on the Isle of Wight from Lymington Pier, close to the Cape Verde team’s training camp base – a YHA hostel in the New Forest. With Cyclist invited along for the ride, we’re heading over the Solent for a training ride and photoshoot for Le Col, one of a few brands to step up and sponsor the team.

‘There’s a lot of correspondence before you get to this point,’ says Savage. ‘I reached out to various potential sponsors. For every positive response you have, there are probably 30 who say no. So I’m incredibly grateful to Le Col, Giant, Abus, Cadex, Wightlink and everybody involved in helping us climb a hurdle and move to the next one.’

The team are riding bikes they picked up only a couple of days prior, from the Giant store in Southampton. Savage chose Hampshire as a base so they could acclimatise to relatively quiet European roads ahead of their debut on the world stage. When they travel north to Scotland for the 2023 World Championships, all six riders will take part in the Gran Fondo, an amateur event with rainbow bands at stake for age group winners in a race around the glens and lochs of Perth, on 4th August.

Cape Verde was among the countries invited as part of the UCI’s efforts to encourage all cycling federations to participate in the first Worlds to integrate all cycling disciplines, with the aim of making ‘cycling the sport of the 21st century, to make it more inclusive’ as part of its 2030 Agenda. As well as the Gran Fondo, the three youngest members of the squad will also ride the Under-23 Time-Trial, with the other three taking part in the senior time-trial – all on road bikes, because they couldn’t get hold of TT ones.

‘Everywhere we look, we’ve faced obstacles and barriers like funding, the lack of UCI-legal bikes – and having no way of getting the money for them without pulling in a couple of favours,’ says Savage, who knows a thing or two about competing at a major event after racing the triathlon final at the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester, representing his birth nation of Kiribati in the central Pacific. ‘But where there’s a will, there’s a way. And we’ll just chalk those hurdles off, one at a time.’

Regardless of what they are riding, Savage’s stable see the Worlds as a huge opportunity.

Nelio Patrick de Cruz – or the ‘Cruz Missile’, as Savage calls him – is 22, from the island of St Vincent. Having not long finished his studies, he’s the Cape Verde national road race and TT champion.

‘Expectations for Glasgow are not that big,’ says Cruz. ‘I want to finish the race and get a good result. My dream is already realised to be in the World Championships. But who knows in the future if I can be a professional rider? That’s a dream also.’

Beyond the Worlds, Cruz’s goal is to be part of the pro peloton. He wants to use the six-month window his visa allows to prove himself to professional teams. When we stop for a pub lunch of fish finger sandwiches, one of the riders asks whether any pro teams will be watching the Gran Fondo with interest.

‘If Nelio wins his category, if he obliterates the field,’ says Savage, ‘they’ll have no choice but to sit up and say: “I wonder what he can do?” But he’s better off doing well at the Under-23 Time-Trial because it’s more of a pro sort of race.’

Second behind Cruz in their national road race was Leo Cosme. At 18 (turning 19 over the Worlds), he is the youngest of the bunch. He is one of four teammates who had to fly more than 700km to Senegalese capital of Dakar to have their biometrics done to obtain a visa, because there’s no British embassy on Cape Verde – another barrier Savage and his team has had to overcome.

Eliezer Soares, 28, works as a policeman on the island of Sal and completes the Cape Verde road race podium. He rides at least 400km a week around his shifts, and will take part in the Worlds TT only three years after taking up cycling when an injured left knee meant he was unable to train in the gym as he used to.

‘I started riding at 25 years old. The doctor said I should ride my bike because it’s good for my injuries.’

Ruben Junior, 22, who has also not long finished his education, is from Santo Antão – known for its fertile craters and cliff-hanging towns, a world away from the tropical beaches of St Vincent. Like Cruz, he is what Savage describes as a ‘top climber’ and wants to show pro teams what he is capable of.

Then there is Renato Soares (no relation), 44, head of the technical department at the Postillion Hotel in Rotterdam.

‘I’m probably the oldest cyclist at this World Championships,’ says Soares. ‘I moved [to the Netherlands] from Cape Verde when I was 21 years old. I joined a club, RWC Ahoy, where a lot of professional cyclists come from, like Dylan van Baarle.

‘In 2004 I was club champion; Rotterdam champion one time. I made a lot of top-10s. Racing in Glasgow is a dream come true. I could never imagine this kind of thing happening with me. For me, it’s not about the result. It’s about being there and passing on my experience to the younger boys, picking up the experience to giving it to our country.’

Soares is aiming for the top 50 in the Gran Fondo. And his goal for the Time-Trial? ‘Not to be last.’

Last on the roster is William ‘Che’ Gomez, 37, who lives in Orlando, Florida, with his wife and two children and owns a food haulage company that operates all over Florida State. He moved to the US, initially to New York, ‘for a better life’. Between telling us about the bike shop his club (Bike Place) is based out of and how he somehow finds the time to ride between 400 and 500 miles a week, he drops into conversation that he used to hit out with former Manchester United and Portugal winger Nani, who has Cape Verdean heritage and played for Orlando City from 2019 to 2021.

‘I’m here for the boys,’ says Gomez. ‘This has never happened for my country, this experience. When Dave called me to give me the news, to come and be part of the team, I was so happy I cried. It’s a dream from when I was back in my country cycling – dreaming to come out of my country and be in a good team. That didn’t come true, but I’m so happy to be here.’

Bravehearts

So, what does success look like for Cape Verde in Scotland?

‘Best-case scenario I’d say is top-60 per cent,’ says Savage. ‘If they hit that, I’d say that goes down as a massive success. Bearing in mind they’re not on TT bikes, and time-trialing isn’t a big thing out in Cape Verde – nowhere near the extent it is here or in European countries. [That’s] because the terrain is so hilly.

‘For these boys to be as good as they are when they’ve faced so many obstacles, they’re primed already… this championships is their shot. Mess it up, they go home – nobody knows them. Get it right, and their life could change completely. I don’t really see a lot in between.’

Savage is keen to underline the help he’s had from others, but particularly his deputy chef de mission, Tom Lipscombe, ‘the man with an eye on the UCI small print’ of accreditations, race briefings and legalities, who has also willingly given his time and expertise to the Cape Verde cause voluntarily. But Savage says far less credit is due to the Cape Verde Cycling Federation (FCC) – though they are happy to take it where they can.

‘They love making out that they’re doing everything for everyone,’ says Savage. ‘They’re trimming all my reports to make it sound like they’re doing it. If there’s anything over here that looks like someone else did it, they don’t include it. It’s a really sad, insecure [way to operate]… I’ve had so many arguments with them, but I know I’m not going to get anywhere.

‘They’re not cyclists… If they didn’t blank us out, people would realise how much we’re doing and how little they are doing… It’s something I don’t like because you’re duping people into thinking that if you’re a keen, up-and-coming cyclist on the islands, you can trust the federation to get you to World Championships level. And that’s a concern I have for the future of Cape Verdean cycling. I think people have a right to know. I’d rather talk honestly and openly – it’s not like I can get sacked.

‘To trigger change, we need transparency of communication. Otherwise we’ll be in the same situation where [we have the] federation chasing their tails, pretending that it’s easy to do this. Because at the moment they’ve no idea what we’ve done over here [on the Isle of Wight]. They will just take the credit. Which is fine – I don’t want the credit… I’m more interested in the islanders not thinking that their federation can get all the aspiring kids to this point. Because the fact remains that if it weren’t for myself and Tom, these boys wouldn’t be going to the World Championships.

The riders very much agree. ‘Without this man and the team he put together, all he has done to help us, all this was never going to happen,’ says Renato Soares. ‘What he is doing, nobody in Cape Verde was able to do these things.’

Aside from setting up the training camp, organising his squad, sorting their equipment, training plans, race prep and being a father figure and mentor to the group, Savage’s list of duties includes food shopping, menu plans and driving the minibus.

‘If Jack of All Trades is a title, then that’s what I am,’ says Savage. ‘I’ve slept very little since they’ve been here. [But] this is their story, not mine.’

Savage’s goals for his team are clear.

‘What I want to do with these boys is open their minds and seize an opportunity that might never come around again. If I draw on my experiences [at the Commonwealth Games] and relate that to what these chaps are doing, I think they can learn from me in terms of: it’s not just about the race; it’s not about the training camp; it’s everything.

‘If they do well at these championships and a team says, “These kids are bloody good, we need to snap these boys up,” or at least stick them in Mallorca for a couple of weeks on a training camp, or a morning in a testing lab – then I think that’s a good result for the championships.

‘They’re hungry. They’re fighters. They’re fearless. And if what comes of this is good results, positive press, more funding, opportunities for these boys, then it’s a job well done.’

Kit maker Le Col is supporting the Cape Verde national team with a custom version of its speedsuit, developed in collaboration with McLaren racing. The Pro training collection featured here is available now at lecol.cc.
